data.title: Auto format: Allman style
UTF-8 problems: characters mysteriously incorrectly encoded
data.body:
Atom 0.155 / Mac OS X 10.10.1

I’ve encountered a problem that I am reasonably certain was caused by Atom, but which I cannot reproduce (and therefore I have no test case to submit). I know how unuseful such a bug report is, but thought you should be aware of the issue.

99% of the time I am programming, and so am pretty much just using ASCII. However, everything is saved in UTF-8, as is usual nowadays and is Atom’s default. During the last couple of days I needed to update a bunch of strings/locales files (de, es, fr, it, ja, pt-BR, zh-Hans, and zh-Hant) and now see several garbled characters have been introduced into lines which previously were good and which I had not edited. (I can tell this from the SVN history, for example in a de file I edited, I can see the line I changed, but also in a line I did not edit I see a ö converted to �.) (The files in question had only been edited by me, only using Atom.)

If I do a Find in Project for � (not scientific, I’m sure, but I’m not sure what else I can do) and restrict it just to the locales directory, I see a lot of results from files that previously were good. I can’t find any way to copy-and-paste from the Find in Project results pane, so here is a screenshot:

![screen shot 2014-12-10 at 17 05 09](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7255543/5393735/1d7b4a94-8135-11e4-8576-5c4b5502326f.png)

Confusingly, some of those files are in fact fine. If I open them by clicking on the line in the Find in Project results pane I do not see the garbled character and the result then disappears from the results pane.

This only happens with seemingly random characters, not all. For example in one pt-BR file a ç became garbled but other instances of the same character did not. Similarly in a de file one ö became garbled but others did not.

Please let me know if there is anything I can do to help pinpoint the issue. Unfortunately I can’t attach the actual locale files as they are private.

data.title: Fixed activateNow when no activation promise
data.body: If you call `Package::activateNow` when Atom is waiting for a command to activate it, then `activateNow` blows up expecting a promise.  This fixes that and allows `activateNow` to be used at any time on a loaded package.

data.title: Better BufferedProcess error handling
data.body:
We've had a lot of errors related to not having some binary installed. The errors are terrible: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4525

These packages are trying to [handle them](https://github.com/nickclaw/atom-grunt-runner/blob/master/lib/grunt-runner-view.coffee#L152), but there is no way without using `bufferedProcess.process.on 'error'` and that is obviously not discoverable. 

Notifications will catch the unhandled errors, and display something nice for them, rather than the fatal notification with a 'create issue' button.
- If there is a handler, just emit the event
- If no handler, throw an error

data.title: Commandline behaviour changed moving from Chocolatey to Squirrl
data.body:
Previously with the chocolatey based install I was able to open a command prompt and type `atom .` to open atom in the current folder, and after that command executed, my prompt would simply continue and allow me to do other things in the folder.

After the new install, when I type `atom .` I get the following output:

```
λ atom .
App load time: 147ms
[4124:1211/011828:INFO:renderer_main.cc(204)] Renderer process started
[4656:1211/011830:INFO:CONSOLE(64)] "Window load time: 2304ms", source: file:///C:/Users/<myuser>/AppData/Local/atom/app-0.156.0/resources/app/static/index.js (64)
[4656:1211/011833:INFO:CONSOLE(536)] "Error deactivating package 'keybinding-resolver'", source: c:\Users\<myuser>\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.156.0\resources\app\src\package.js (536)
```

And it blocks my prompt. I can either close Atom to get back to my prompt or CTRL-C (which obviously kills Atom)

Is it possible to get the old behaviour back?

data.title: getting red notifications when saving keymap.cson with parse error
data.body:
Yet another notification annoyance.

I save all the time with errors.  If I am in the middle of edits and I need to do something else I automatically save.  Now I'm getting red notifications when saving keymap.cson with parse error.  This is very annoying.

There has to be some way to control the notifications better.  At least let them be turned off.

data.title: Update Chocolatey package to call the new Squirrel based installer
data.body:
I understand that Chocolatey is no longer required due to the new Squirrel installer for Windows, but many Chocolatey users prefer to manage their installs using Chocolatey to allow scripted box builds.

I don't see a repo for the Atom Chocolatey package, but I'd just change the Install.ps1 to this:

```
$packageName = 'Atom'
$url = 'https://atom.io/download/windows'
$installerType = 'exe'
$installArgs = '/quiet'
Install-ChocolateyPackage $packageName $installerType $installArgs $url
```

Note that this calls the [/quiet install arg](https://github.com/Squirrel/Squirrel.Windows/blob/master/src/Setup/winmain.cpp) on Squirrel's Setup.exe.

data.title: "Reveal in Tree View" shifts window by 1 pixel
data.body: Right clicking on a chunk of text and clicking "Reveal in Tree View" shifts the contents of the window over by approx. ~1 pixel each time you do it. After doing that several times there is a noticeable cutoff on the right and margin on the left.

data.title: Start and end comment strings should be paired explicitly in scoped config
data.body:
## The Problem

Currently, language packages specify comment strings via the `editor.commentStart` and `editor.commentEnd` scoped config values. This requires us to use an awkward private method on config in [`language-mode.coffee`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/language-mode.coffee#L33) to retrieve the comment strings so that pairs match up. If we retrieve each comment string separately with `atom.config.get`, it's possible that we'll retrieve the start and end comment strings from different scopes if the more specific scope doesn't have both values.
## The Solution

Since language mode is private, we could continue to use the private method, but it violates Atom's spirit of extensibility to rely on a private method to perform an action as fundamental as retrieving paired comments strings in a scope.

The better solution is to add another link to the key path, using `editor.comment.start` and `editor.comment.end` as our key paths. Then we can call `atom.config.get("editor.comment")` to get a single object containing one or both keys.
## What should we do?

This is an API change because the settings in language packages will need to be changed. We could potentially do this change after the freeze and just leave things deprecated until 2.0, but I would rather get it in since it's not that big a change. I would rather not carry it as technical debt until 2.0. The following steps will be required:
- Read from the new key path.
- Shim the old values when loading packages and log a deprecation warning.
- Modify our TextMate converter to use the new key paths for the start/end comment strings.
- Change bundled language packages.

/cc @atom/core

data.title: Windows releases late again.
data.body: On chocolately windows releases were late due to the approval process.  Now I'm seeing late releases on the new installer.  Mine is still 153.
